div1.p: Carter provides family news and discusses his land in Florida.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, April 13, 1890
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of______, Surgeon's Office,
April 13, 1890
Dear Mother:
div1.p:
We are in status quo & I assume likely so to
continue. The only ripple on the course of our present life is that
the Steward is going to Wh. O. to have Mand's teeth fixed,
& that isn't very exciting save to the participants.

I will have to go to Biloxi, once more this month & I pre-
sume only once more, & then the Quarantine. A long hot,
insecty & anxious six 1/2 months. However the work
this season is slight as compared with that of last,
& at present as nothing. I rec'd notice last mail that
I shall appear before the next examinging board.
That does not mean immediate promotion unfortu-
nately, only that if I pass all right I will be eligi-
ble for the next vacancy. I have no idea when
the said Board will meet. I heard this month & also
heard in June. If relievedordered off now I must be relieved
Hankins, Dr. Lennon
Peter Blanchard
La. Board of Health
C1
B22
840
As Pensicola & Apilachicola lay Quarantine
with 15th inst & an officer must be here now.
This will probably give me an opportunity to see
you this summer as I could doubtless
stop a few days on my return I presume
the Board will meet in Washington
I am ill prepared for a professional examination -
especially on the so-called “Student Branches,” the work
here having displaced such knowledge from my mind.
But it seems that most stress is laid on Practice of Medicine
Surgery & Pathology & those are branches one does not forget.
I must say that I wish I could get my promotion soon. I need
the increase of salary. Would send L& the children on to Va
if I had it in May.

Tell Mary we received the two Scribners & were
very glad to get them although I have only read in them
Laura's eyes are getting strong, it seems to me to have been
a weakened power of accommodation due to strain
of a naturally far-sighted eye when very weak.
I rec'd a note from my Fla. man, who said that the old
trees came through (the freeze) uninjured, but that moremany
of those set out in February (& which had not rooted) were
killed. He seemed to ascribe the loss as much (or more)
to the dry weather as to the cold - as the blossoms were unin-
jured on the bearing trees. He promised to write more fully next
mail; it (writing) is not easy to him I think.

How is John getting on at school? (or College rather) & when will he be
able to leave it? Nine others of us had the grippe same L. & I. I wonder
if you would have had it if I had not. I think it doubtful.

We have been pretty near starvation recently (save the steward) I
was alone here & could not by myself haul the seine. The fish would not
bite & meat was scarce, & if crabs had not come up we had
fared badly

All send love & all-save possibly L. Jr - are to some
extent ailing - Henry especially so.
